references.text: One patent was awarded to each of these two inventors. Atalla's patent [73], filed second but granted first claims an analog transistor device operation in the punch-through or space charge limited mode. Kahng's patent [74], filed first but granted second, claims a circuit arrangement or circuit configuration to operate the device. Kahng's patent describes a MOSFET with two diffused p-type region on an n-type silicon and Atalla's patent describes one with two diffused n-type region on an intrinsic or high resistivity p-type or pi-type silicon. In the personal account by Kahng given in [71], he claims that all the possible current-voltage characteristics were presented at the Solid State Device Research conference and predicted by his unpublished analyses made in Jan. 1961 [75]. This claim is supported by Kahng's drain current equation (22)' {Ip = [sμεf/2δ]Vp(Vf - Vp/2) where s is the channel width divided by the channel length, μ is the hole mobility in the surface channel, εf is the dielectric constant of the gate oxide, Vp is the drain-to-source voltage, and Vf is the gate (or field plate) voltage.} and the computed current voltage characteristics given in Kahng's figure 6 for the experimental p-channel MOSFET with boron diffused source and drain regions in an n-type silicon.

references.text: John Aiken and Richard Aiken, Power: The Gift of Niagara, Buffalo and Erie County Historical Society, 1962 is a popular account. More primary source than interpretive history is Edward Dean Adams, Niagara Power: History of the Niagara Falls Power Company, 1886-1918, 2 volumes, Niagara Falls, N.Y.: Privately printed for the Niagara Falls Power Company, 1927, a wonderfully complete history of the Niagara power project including lengthy excerpts from important documents. While not very good history, it is an excellent sourcebook, making available much information on all aspects of the project. The Harnessing of Niagara, New York and London: Cassier Magazine Company, 1895, is a special volume of Cassier's Magazine devoted to the Niagara project. It is especially useful for technical details of the system adopted. The story of the founding of the Niagara reservation is told in The Distinctive Charms of Niagara Scenery: Frederick Law Olmsted and the Niagara Reservation, Niagara Falls, New York: Buscaglia-Castellani Art Gallery of Niagara University, 1985.

Indeed, almost all of the reminiscences of the engineers concerned with the decision insist that there could have been no other way, and historians have all too often followed them in that assumption. See, for example, Aiken and Aiken, Power, p. 10. One Russian historian has gone so far as to claim that "the replacement of mechanical transmission by electric transmission... was historically predetermined," (L.I. Uvarov, "On the History of the Distant Transmission of Mechanical Energy," Actes VIIIe Congres Internationale d'Histoire des Sciences, 1958, pp. 984-86). The Russian school of the history of technology exaggerates one of the failings of too much history of technology: its insistence on projecting the facts and achievements of the present upon the story of the past, as though the technology of the past were rationally directed toward the present. On the historiography of inevitability, see Eugene S. Ferguson, "Toward a Discipline of the History of Technology," Technology and Culture 15: 19, June 1974.

references.text: In the nineteenth century, the word "sublime ' was used to describe a scene evoking the positive emotions of awe, dread, and grandeur. The closest colloquial expression today is, perhaps, "Awesome!" The English usually applied it to the natural landscape, but in the United States, it was increasingly applied to machinery; see Kasson, Civilizing the Machine, pp. 166-174.

An article "Electricity at Niagara Falls," American Electrician, June, 1897, pp. 211-19 makes the point: "The subject of this article is perhaps the most hackneyed in the entire range of periodical literature; indeed, it would be difficult to find a commercial development in any branch of industry which has been more exhaustively described." references.text: The Cataract Construction Company was supported by some of the leading investment bankers in the United States, including J. Pierpont Morgan, William Vanderbilt and the firms of Drexel Morgan and Company, Winslow, Lanier and Company, and Brown Brothers and Company. The initial bond offering raised \$2,500,000. Passer, The Electrical Manufacturers, p. 284. The first team of engineers sent overseas consisted of Edward Adams, president of the CCC and Coleman Sellers, chief engineer. The second team, sent a few months later, consisted of Francis Stetson, vice-president, and John Bogart, engineer. Their assignment was to examine projects and question authorities; they were not authorized to make the decision. The details of the tours are given in Adams, Niagara Power, I, 164-172 and I, 184-85 and in Francis Lynde Stetson, "The Use of the Niagara Water Power," in The Harnessing of Niagara, pp. 186-88.

references.text: The advice of each of the consultants is summarized in Adams, Niagara Power, 1,144-156. It is unclear whether Westinghouse was a paid consultant; his advice was tendered to Stetson in 1890, see Stetson, "Uses," p. 186.
Details of the International Niagara Commission are given in Adams, Niagara Power, chapter 10; the Letter of Invitation is reproduced ibid., I, 395-399.

The panel included Sir William Thomson (Lord Kelvin), physicist and electrical engineer of Glasgow, president; Coleman Sellers, professor of engineering practice and mechanics at the Stevens Institute of Technology and the Franklin Institute and chief engineer of the Cataract Construction Company; E. Mascart, a physicist and director of the French Bureau Central Meteorologique; Theodore Turrettini, an engineer and physicist from Geneva; and William Cawthorne Unwin, an english engineer with expertise in civil, electrical and mechanical engineering and an authority on the transmission of power. With the exception of Sellers, all of the members of the committee had both theoretical and practical experience with electrical work. It seems weighted toward scientific, not engineering, expertise, which may help to explain why it found no scheme completely suitable. On the deliberations of the Commission, see Adams, Niagara Power, pp. 180-192.
proposals submitted to the Commission are outlined in William C. Unwin, "Report on the Projects Submitted to the International Niagara Commission," reprinted in Adams, Niagara Power, I, 403-445.

Quoted in Adams, Niagara Power, 1,191-92. It is not clear who Sellers had in mind as the "visionary schemer or inventor." He may have been a promoter of alternating current, possibly either George Forbes or George Westinghouse. The Commission's view of alternating current was later noted by Forbes: In 1890, when preparing plans to lay before the Commission, I proposed to employ alternating currents, using as motors either the alternating dynamo or the multiphase motor, which has since attracted so much attention at Frankfort last year. This was an innovation on previous practice, and it is worthy of record that the Commission were unanimous (with one exception) in desiring to pass a resolution, saying that alternating currents were not available for the purpose. Already opinion has changed and the subsequent progress has so completely borne out the views expressed in 1890 that we are going to adopt this method. (Letter to the London Times, quoted in Scientific American, 58: (3) 33, July 16, 1892.
Forbes was hired as consulting engineer by the Cataract Construction Company in April 1892
Westinghouse received the contract for the work in 1893; and of course ac was eventually adopted.
